Question: What are the symptoms of Parkinson's Disease?
Answer: The four main symptoms of Parkinsons disease are: - tremor or trembling in hands, arms, legs, jaw, or head  - rigidity, or stiffness of the limbs and trunk  - bradykinesia, or slowness of movement  - postural instability, or impaired balance. tremor or trembling in hands, arms, legs, jaw, or head rigidity, or stiffness of the limbs and trunk bradykinesia, or slowness of movement postural instability, or impaired balance. Other signs and symptoms may include depression; other emotional changes; problems with speech; urinary problems; sleep disruptions; skin problems; and orthostatic hypotension (a sudden drop in blood pressure when standing up).

Question: How is HIV/AIDS diagnosed?
Answer: HIV testing is done using blood samples. The most common test used to diagnose HIV infection is the enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) test, which detects antibodies to HIV in a blood sample. A positive ELISA result means that HIV antibodies were found in the blood sample and more testing is needed to confirm the diagnosis. If the ELISA test is positive, a Western blot test is usually performed to confirm the diagnosis. A Western blot test detects specific proteins made by HIV.     If you have been exposed to HIV through sex or sharing needles, getting tested right away can help determine whether you are infected. However, it takes time for your body to make enough antibodies for an accurate test result. If you get tested too soon, you may test negative even if you are infected. Health care providers recommend waiting at least 3 months after possible exposure before getting tested.    Stopping app - local entrypoint completed.

Question: How can I manage my Dengue Fever?
Answer: - Get plenty of rest.  - Drink lots of fluids, such as fruit juices and sports drinks. Avoid drinks with caffeine.  - Take acetaminophen (Tylenol) for pain. Do not take aspirin or ibuprofen because they may increase bleeding.

Question: Can Glaucoma be prevented?
Answer: Glaucoma is a complex disease with many risk factors. Some of these risk factors cannot be changed, such as age and race. However, there are several things you can do to reduce your risk of glaucoma: - Have a comprehensive dilated eye exam at least once a year.  - If you have diabetes or a family history of glaucoma, have a comprehensive dilated eye exam every year.  - If you are African American, have a comprehensive dilated eye exam every two years.  - If you are Hispanic American, have a comprehensive dilated eye exam every three years.  - If you are Asian American, have a comprehensive dilated eye exam every year.  Have a comprehensive dilated eye exam at least once a year. If you have diabetes or a family history of glaucoma, have a comprehensive dilated eye exam every year. If you are African American, have a comprehensive dilated eye exam every two years. If you are Hispanic American, have a comprehensive dilated eye exam every three years. If you are Asian American, have a comprehensive dilated eye exam every year.

Question: Can Endometriosis be prevented?
Answer: Endometriosis cannot be prevented. However, there are things you can do to reduce your risk of developing endometriosis. These include:    - Avoiding smoking  - Eating a healthy diet  - Exercising regularly

Question: How can I manage my Multiple Sclerosis?
Answer: There is no cure for multiple sclerosis (MS), but there are treatments that may slow it down and help you manage your symptoms. Treatments include medicines, physical therapy, exercise, and other therapies.            They can help you stay active and independent. Medicines Your doctor will prescribe medicines to treat the symptoms of MS. These medicines may include:                Interferon beta-1a or interferon beta-1b. These medicines reduce relapses and slow disability progression.            Glatiramer acetate. This medicine reduces relapses and slows disability progression.                Dimethyl fumarate. This medicine reduces relapses and slows disability progression.                Fingolimod. This medicine reduces relapses and slows disability progression.                Counseling. Counseling can help you adjust to having a chronic illness.

Question: How is Cancer diagnosed?
Answer:
Cancer is diagnosed with a biopsy. A biopsy is a procedure that involves taking a sample of cells or tissues     so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer. The type of biopsy performed         depends on the size and location of the tumor, as well as other factors.
        The following are some common types of biopsies:
        -  Fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy. An FNA biopsy uses a thin needle to remove fluid and/or cells from a         lump or mass in the body. The fluid and/or cells are then examined under a microscope to look for cancer cells.         This type of biopsy is often used to diagnose thyroid cancer.  -  Core needle biopsy. A core needle biopsy uses a        larger needle to remove a small piece of tissue from a lump or mass in the body. The tissue is then examined under a             microscope to look for cancer cells. This type of biopsy is often used to diagnose breast cancer. - ional biopsy.                  An incisional biopsy removes part of a lump or suspicious area of tissue.The tissue is then examined under a microscope to look for cancer cells. This type of biopsy may be     used to diagnose skin cancer.  -  Excisional biopsy. An excisional biopsy removes an entire lump or area of tissue that doesnt look normal.         The tissue is then examined under a microscope to look for cancer cells. This type of biopsy may be used to diagnose melanoma.  -  Laparoscopy.             Laparoscopy is a surgical procedure that uses a thin tube called a laparoscope to look at the organs inside the abdomen to help find out if cancer                has spread there. Small instruments may be inserted through the same incision to take tissue samples. The tissue samples are then examined under                     a microscope to look for cancer cells. This type of biopsy may be used to diagnose ovarian cancer.  -  Thoracentesis. Thoracentesis is a procedure that uses a needle to remove fluid from the space between the lining of the chest and the lung. A pathologist views the fluid under a microscope to look for cancer cells. This type of biopsy may be used to diagnose mesothelioma.  -  Thorascopy. Thorascopy is a surgical procedure that uses a small camera on the end of a thin tube to look at the organs inside the chest to help find out if cancer has spread there. Small instruments may be inserted through the same incision to take tissue samples. The tissue samples are then examined under a microscope to look for cancer cells. This type of biopsy may be used to diagnose lung cancer.  -  Bronchoscopy. Bronchoscopy is a procedure that uses a thin, flexible tube to look inside the trachea and large airways in the lung. A bronchoscope may also have a light and a lens for viewing. A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells. This type of biopsy may be used to diagnose lung cancer.  -  Mediastinoscopy. Mediastinoscopy is a surgical procedure that uses a thin, tube-like instrument to look at the organs, tissues, and lymph nodes between the lungs for abnormal areas. A mediastinoscope may also have a light and a lens for viewing. Small instruments may be inserted through the same incision to take tissue samples. The tissue samples are then examined under a microscope to look for cancer cells. This type of biopsy may be used to diagnose lung cancer.  -  Colonoscopy. Colonoscopy is a procedure that uses a long, flexible, narrow tube with a light and a lens for viewing (colonoscope) to look inside the rectum and the colon for polyps or abnormal areas. A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells. This type of biopsy may be used to diagnose colorectal cancer.  -  Cystoscopy. Cystoscopy is a procedure that uses a long, thin, tube-like instrument with a light and a lens for viewing (cystoscope) to look inside the bladder and urethra for abnormal areas. A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells. This type of biopsy may be used to diagnose bladder cancer.  -  Prostate biopsy. Question: What treatment options are available for Endometriosis?
Answer:
Treatment for endometriosis depends on the severity of symptoms and whether 
a woman wants to have children. The goals of treatment include relieving pain, preventing 
scarring, and preserving fertility.

Question: How can I manage my Diabetes?
Answer:
You can manage your diabetes by taking care of yourself. You will need to take medicine, eat healthy foods, be physically active on a regular basis, and keep your blood glucose, blood pressure, and cholesterol under control.
        - Medicine. Your doctor may prescribe insulin or oral medicines to help you control your blood glucose levels.  - Eating healthy foods. You should eat a variety of healthy foods every day.  - Physical activity. Being physically active helps your body use the insulin it makes or takes in. It also lowers your blood glucose level and helps you lose weight.  - Blood glucose, blood pressure, and cholesterol. Keeping these numbers in your target range will help prevent complications from diabetes.

Question: How is Dengue Fever diagnosed?
Answer:
Dengue fever is usually diagnosed based on the symptoms, travel history and laboratory tests. The diagnosis of dengue fever can be difficult because there are no specific signs or symptoms in the early stages of the disease. In addition, the symptoms of dengue fever are similar to those of other tropical diseases like malaria and typhoid fever.
  
The following laboratory tests may be used to help diagnose dengue fever:
  
   - Blood test for antibodies to dengue virus (IgM)
   - Blood test for dengue virus antigen
   - Blood test for dengue virus RNA
